content:
UK/EU

UK House of Lords approved legislation forcing PM May to delay Brexit and avoid no-deal Brexit on April 12th and sends legislation back to Lower House for vote. (Newswires)

UK PM May is reportedly considering giving MPs a free vote on whether to hold a second referendum, although reports also noted that the Brexit Chief Whip is confident the government has the numbers to defeat any vote on a second referendum. (Telegraph)

UK Conservative party spokesperson says it remains the government’s intention to ratify a deal that allows a Brexit before 23 May 2019, so that we do not need to participate in European elections. (Newswires)

EU wants UK to approve Brexit deal this week or face a long delay and are to consider 9-month or 12-month extension if a withdrawal deal isn't approved by Friday. Furthermore, the reports noted the EU want to be able to end the extension period if a new Brexiteer PM tries to cause problems during a long extension. (BuzzFeed)

UK opposition Labour Party was said to have received an updated offer from government as part of ongoing Brexit negotiations, although there were later comments from Labour leader Corbyn that the government does not seem to be moving from red lines and so far Labour has not seen the commitments it wanted to see. (Newswires)

Cabinet Office confirmed the government laid a Day of Poll Order needed for Euro elections and stated they have taken the necessary steps required by law should the UK have to participate. (Twitter)

Sources suggest the most likely outcome of Wednesday's emergency Brexit summit is an extension of the Brexit deadline to the end of May, according to ITV’s Peston. (Twitter)

A rumour was swirling around parliament that the EU and UK could agree a 9-month Brexit extension to the end of the year, according to The Daily Telegraph's Christopher Hope. (Twitter)

UK PM May has been warned by some members of the 1922 executive that a customs union is unacceptable, according to BBC’s Nick Eardley. (Twitter)

MARKET RECAP

Versum Materials (VSM) surged on a new buyout offer from Merck AG (MRK GY). Symantec Corp (SYMC) shares traded higher after Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock. Amazon (AMZN) caught a tailwind following an upgrade at SocGen to a Buy rating. P&G Corp (PG) shares traded higher after a Wells Fargo analyst turned bullish on the stock. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) shares rose after an analyst at Jefferies upgraded Wynn to a buy rating. Oil and oil related companies (SLB, COG, CXO, EOG) outperformed on the day off the back of advances in crude after conflict in Libya escalated. General Electric (GE) shares traded lower after JP Morgan analyst Stephen Tulsa downgraded the conglomerate. Boeing (BA) shares were hit after a cut to its monthly 737 Max production rate (from 52 to 42) and Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded its outlook for the stock. Dollar Tree (DLTR) shares traded lower after activist investor Starboard Value LP withdrew its nominations for directors on the dollar stores board. Southwest Airlines (LUV) shares traded lower after being downgraded by Raymond James on concerns that the Boeing 737 Max grounding could last through summer. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) shares fell after it pledged to invest USD 800mln in Alnylam Pharmaceuticals. SPX +0.1% at 2896, NDX +0.3% at 7600, DJI -0.3% at 26341.

US Treasury yields rose by 1.5bps-2bps at settlement. However, the day started off with a bid, and weak German data lent support. However, over the course of the session, the complex gradually eased, with some citing chunky supply this week out of the US Treasury, as well as the corporate slate (books on Aramco's USD 10bln M&A bonds are said to be above USD 60bln). Lower volatility in equities and generally stable S&P also left little need for the haven, while some also cited increased chatter about the reflation trade, too. Some suggest that the rate cut pricing in Fed funds might be a function of the Fed's independence under threat (Board nominee Moore has called for rate cuts recently, as has NEC director Kudlow), however, with optimism that a US/China trade deal can help boost global growth, and stabilising metrics in China too (which can feed through into Europe), there are certainly questions about the need for immediately looser policy. Ahead of FOMC minutes this week, money markets price under 50% chance of a rate cut in 2019 (vs over 50% at the end of last week). Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement. US T-note futures (M9) settled 4+ ticks lower at 123-14+.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 8 April 2019: Crude jumps amid Libyan tensions
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities mixed, dollar down, Treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Libyan tensions rise; Boeing cuts 737 MAX production; US factory orders in line; Lords approve Brexit deal, send it back to Commons.

* AHEAD: US NFIB Business Optimism; EIA Short Term; Outlook & Summer Fuels Outlook; Fed's Quarles & Clarida; Supply from Japan, UK & US.

* BREXIT: UK PM May on Sunday defended her strategy to reach out to opposition Labour, warning that without opposition support, Brexit might not happen. Cross-party talks are expected to resume this week, despite the limited progress made amid conflicting reports last week. If an agreement remains elusive, there is a chance of further indicative votes ahead of Wednesday's emergency EU summit (May will meet Macron and Merkel in advance of the meetings to set out her rationale for the extension). In the event both approaches fail to garner a majority for May's deal, May hopes EU leaders will grant a request to extend the Article 50 process until 30 June, although there may be reluctance from the EU27 if May has little to offer in terms of how she intends to proceed to try and avoid a no-deal Brexit. As things stand, the UK will leave the EU on Friday 12 April, though the consensus sees at least some extension being granted. In the Upper House, the Lords approved legislation forcing PM May to delay Brexit and avoid no-deal Brexit on 12 April; sends legislation back to Lower House for vote, forcing UK PM May to consult Parliament on any delay; it may also give Parliament the power to scrutinise May’s request for an extension. The law is likely to be voted through the Commons later Monday or on Tuesday. From the EU perspective, the EU wants UK to approve Brexit deal this week or face a long delay, according to BuzzFeed, which reported that the EU27 are to consider a 9-month or 12-month extension if a withdrawal deal isn't approved by Friday; if a new Brexiteer PM tries to cause problems during a long extension, the EU want to be able to end the extension period.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 1.32 HIGHER AT USD 64.40/BBL; BRENT (M9) SETTLES USD 0.76 HIGHER AT USD 71.10/BBL. The oil complex continued its rally at the start of the week, printing fresh YTD highs, with supply very much being a driving force. The dominating narrative is the ongoing conflict in Libya, as the Eastern forces continue to clash with the Western forces over control over the city of Tripoli, and surrounding arrears, concerns over the country’s ability to export its approximate 1.1mln BPD capacity grow larger. Whilst the OPEC member’s current oil operations remain unaffected, with key oil fields – such as El Sharara – far away from the conflict, history in the region suggests the country’s exporting facilities could be forfeited if the Tripoli-based National Oil Corp.’s export terminals are captured by the Eastern forces; a similar situation occurred back in June 2018. However, although Brent saw gains, it was WTI that saw the most gains, in particular the May contract. Analyst at Citi comment, “this could be the result of a technical squeeze, surprising strength after the DOE reported an unexpected 7.2mln bbls build in commercial crude stocks for last week, but may also be signalling a concern that US exports are too high, or will be once refiners complete seasonal maintenance work.” Also likely to be playing into the narrowing of the WTI/Brent Arb are some slightly bearish comments from Saudi Arabia and Russia, where Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the market is moving towards balance and that the Kingdom sees no need for additional production cuts; Russian officials also hinted that the OPEC+ group should raise its output in June. Looking ahead, current expectations for US energy inventories – for the recent week – see crude stocks building 2.5mln bbls; both the products are seen drawing, distillates by 1.4mln bbls, and gasoline by 2.1mln bbls.

* SPX +0.1% at 2896, NDX +0.3% at 7600, DJI -0.3% at 26341. SECTORS: Energy +0.0%, Materials +0.0%, Industrials -0.0%, Communications +0.6%, Cons Discretionary +0.4%, Cons Staples +0.4%, Healthcare -0.0%, Financials +0.1%, Tech +0.4%, Telecoms -0.2%, Utilities -0.7%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Versum Materials (VSM) surged on a new buyout offer from Merck AG (MRK GY). Symantec Corp (SYMC) shares traded higher after Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock. Amazon (AMZN) caught a tailwind following an upgrade at SocGen to a Buy rating. P&G Corp (PG) shares traded higher after a Wells Fargo analyst turned bullish on the stock. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) shares rose after an analyst at Jefferies upgraded Wynn to a buy rating. Oil and oil related companies (SLB, COG, CXO, EOG) outperformed on the day off the back of advances in crude after conflict in Libya escalated. General Electric (GE) shares traded lower after JP Morgan analyst Stephen Tulsa downgraded the conglomerate. Boeing (BA) shares were hit after a cut to its monthly 737 Max production rate (from 52 to 42) and Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded its outlook for the stock. Dollar Tree (DLTR) shares traded lower after activist investor Starboard Value LP withdrew its nominations for directors on the dollar stores board. Southwest Airlines (LUV) shares traded lower after being downgraded by Raymond James on concerns that the Boeing 737 Max grounding could last through summer. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) shares fell after it pledged to invest USD 800mln in Alnylam Pharmaceuticals.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 4+ TICKS LOWER AT 123-14+. US Treasury yields rose by 1.5bps-2bps at settlement. However, the day started off with a bid, and weak German data lent support. However, over the course of the session, the complex gradually eased, with some citing chunky supply this week out of the US Treasury, as well as the corporate slate (books on Aramco's USD 10bln M&A bonds are said to be above USD 60bln). Lower volatility in equities and generally stable S&P also left little need for the haven, while some also cited increased chatter about the reflation trade, too. Some suggest that the rate cut pricing in Fed funds might be a function of the Fed's independence under threat (Board nominee Moore has called for rate cuts recently, as has NEC director Kudlow), however, with optimism that a US/China trade deal can help boost global growth, and stabilising metrics in China too (which can feed through into Europe), there are certainly questions about the need for immediately looser policy. Ahead of FOMC minutes this week, money markets price under 50% chance of a rate cut in 2019 (vs over 50% at the end of last week). Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement.

* WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 38bln, Tue), 10-year (USD 24bln, Wed) and 30-year (USD 16blnm Thu). With USD 77.8bln maturing at month-end settlement, the auctions will raise around USD 200mln in new cash, according to TD Securities. The bank adds that with USD 180mln maturing on the Fed's balance sheet, there will be nearly no add-ons at mid-month settlement. Recent auctions have generally performed well, with investors piling into havens at the beginning of the year amid the market uncertainty. While market pricing remains elevated (around 50% chance of a rate cut by the end of the year), it has backed off from extremes. TD Securities expects that, with the Fed's balance sheet run-off ending in October, the bank expects the Treasury to cut auction sizes in the 2-year to 3-year sector, which could support demand at the front-end.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Cover was higher at the previous 3-year auction to the highest in 2019 (2.6x) even as yields declined in the run up to the auction. Final demand, however, was somewhat weak, Barclays notes, with dealers taking down marginally more supply than the first two auctions in the year. The prior auctions tailed by 0.4bps, which was wider than the recent average around 0.2bps. In terms of the upcoming auction, Barclays says the current 3-year note (the March 2022) is a potential deferred cheapest-to-date candidate in TUM0 and trades rich on the curve, similar to other deferred TU CTD securities (ie, Dec21s, Sep21s, and Jun21s). As a result, Barclays estimates that the WI should trade at a liquidity discount to current 3s. "Furthermore, the quoted roll is biased higher due to the 0.6bps bad day adjustment in the WI; the bond matures on Good Friday (April 15, 2022), which is no settlement," adding that they believe that the WI roll is appropriately priced."

* FX WRAP: The Greenback traded with an offered tone. EUR was done no favours by a downside surprise to the German trade data; however, the EUR was reportedly a beneficiary of short-covering, according to some newswires, while upbeat China data and ‘progress’ in US/China talks has supported the currency, helping to avoid another YTD low. GBP was supported by the weaker buck, and generally shrugged-off Brexit uncertainty, though couldn’t eke out gains against the EUR. As we have been in recent weeks, many analysts now are upping their warnings about the potential of a no deal Brexit, perhaps as soon as Friday in a worst-case scenario. Havens benefited from the Buck’s weakness; gold jumped to a week high above $1,300, also seeing interest as equities struggled at times. The JPY broke above its 200dma around 111.50 and has been magnetic to that level since – some desks note chunky expiries at Tuesday’s NY Cut between 111.00 the figure and 111.40, as well as the 112.00 level. The dollar’s weakness lent support to the EMFX complex, though TRY was the outlier with President Erdogan’s party ha suggested the role of crime in the recent local elections, arguing that the mayoral race in Istanbul was too close to concede.

However, loose policy is expected to continue, and overnight, the government stated it would support SMEs by helping to lower funding costs via certain preferential monetary policies, and make access to capital markets and accelerated IPOs easier.

Daily FX Wrap: Norwegian Krona crowns G10 currency gains
content:
NOK

The Norwegian Crown is sharply outperforming as oil prices extend their bull run amidst escalating trouble in Libya and reaffirmed guidance from the Norges Bank via Governor Ohlsen who maintains that the next rate hike is likely to be rolled out in H2 this year. Indeed, Eur/Nok is down around 9.6150 even though the single currency has cleared chart resistance and recent peaks vs the Dollar – see below.

DXY 

The index has pulled back further from best levels amidst broad Dollar losses and is now testing bids and psychological interest at the 97.000 level after US data showing a decline in factory orders and durable goods (latter mostly unrevised from soft prelim prints). The DXY is holding just above the base of a 97.384-96.976 range and eyeing technical support at 96.806 (March 22 low).

SEK/EUR

The Swedish Krona has overcome some weak Swedish manufacturing orders to post gains vs the Eur in line with its Scandi peer and also on the back of a relatively hawkish Riksbank vs ECB, as the cross probes below 10.4100. However, Eur/Usd has breached heavy resistance circa 1.1250 to reach 1.1275 including a Fib, multi-highs since testing ytd lows under 1.1200 which were made after March’s dovish ECB policy meeting. On that note, this month’s meeting falls on Wednesday due to the end of week IMF gathering that President Draghi is attending and we have a full preview available on the Research Suite that can be found via our headline feed too.

CAD

Another major currency to benefit from the latest leg up in crude and a generally weak Usd, as the Loonie continues its strong recovery from last Friday’s lows (post contrasting Canadian and US payrolls) and shrugs off more disappointing data in the form of housing starts and building permits. Indeed, Usd/Cad has retreated further from 1.3400+ through its 100 DMA (1.3329) and eyeing 1.3300-1.3296 next (latter representing the April low so far from last Wednesday).

AUD/NZD/JPY 

The next best G10 units as the Aussie climbs above its 55 DMA (0.7118) towards 0.7130 and the Kiwi moves away from decent option expiries at 0.6725 to retest 0.6750, while the Jpy has peered above 111.30.

GBP/CHF

Both ending Monday’s EU session firmer vs the Greenback, but modestly compared to the gains noted elsewhere. Cable is still pivoting 1.3050 awaiting more Brexit news as UK PM May and the Labour Party continue to try and thrash out a deal before the former heads off for Pre-EU Summit meetings with German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron. Note, latest reports suggest that the opposition party has received an updated offer, but it remains unclear whether a customs union if included. Meanwhile, the Lords will meet later to debate the Cooper bill that was passed by the HoC by the narrowest margin last week and will give Parliament blocking rights against a no deal via forcing the Government to request and extension beyond April 12. Turning to the Franc, and having stuck near parity in early trade Usd/Chf is now closer to the bottom of a range that has extended to 0.9978.

EM 

The Try is off worst levels, but still languishing amidst the ongoing municipal election result recount in Istanbul and Ankara, Turkey contemplating military action in Syria, the CBRT’s FX swap rate cut (150 bp) and decision to restart 1 week repos. The Lira remains around 5.7000 vs the Dollar.

subject: BREXIT ANALYSIS & WEEK AHEAD
content:
*WHERE WE STAND: At the back end of last week, UK PM May sent a letter to the European Council requesting a Brexit extension to June 30th (currently April 12th) with potential to terminate early should a deal be ratified before then. PM May also stated that preparations have commence for the UK to take part in the European Parliamentary elections on May 23rd.

 

*MIDDLE GROUND: Talks between the UK government and opposition party continue with further talks expected this week in search of a compromise. It seems as though talks are not going as smoothly as some had expected, with source reports on Friday noting that Brexit talks between PM May and Labour leader Corbyn are not going well. The Labour leader noted that he was "waiting to see the red lines move" and had not "noticed any great change in the government's position", whilst the Labour MP Long-Bailey (who is involved in Labour talks with the government) said, over the weekend, that Labour was yet to see the compromise proposals needed to agree a deal. Furthermore, sources cited by BBC's Eardley stated that the Labour party want a firm indication that the government is prepared to reopen the political declaration, there may be some movement later (either talks or a new offer). The UK Foreign Minister Hunt added to this rhetoric by stating that talks with Labour are not easy.

Early on Monday, there were reports that UK PM May could offer the Labour Party a post-Brexit customs union, with weekend press reporting that PM May PM May is set to offer Jeremy Corbyn a legally binding soft Brexit deal with a “Boris lock” that would make it difficult for a future Eurosceptic prime minister to tear up after she leaves No 10. The mechanics of this deal is not yet known.

 

*EU RHETORIC: The 27 European heads of state and government will convene on the invitation on European Council President Donald Tusk on Wednesday 10th April. On Friday, it was reported that EU's Tusk is preparing to offer the UK a 12-month flexible extension which would permit the UK to leave as early as 1st July if the UK has passed with Withdrawal Agreement by that point, according to a senior EU official.

The leaders are set to discuss an extension to Brexit in order to avoid the UK crashing out of the EU. Where do they currently stand?

  • GERMANY: EU sources stated that German Chancellor Merkel is open to backing PM May’s request for a short Brexit extension. Sources also noted that the Chancellor seeks to keep pressure on UK MPs to support the Withdrawal Agreement.
  • FRANCE: France has been dragging its heels in regard to an extension, with the country stating (multiple times) that a clear plan needs to be set out for an extension to be permitted. On Friday, a source close to French President Macron suggests that talk of a further extension to Article 50 is premature and the EU 27 criteria for an extension (a credible alternative plan) has not been met yet.
  • IRELAND: The Irish PM stated that it is “extremely unlikely” that an EU 27 country will veto a request to delay Brexit, although he stated that his own preference was for a longer extension that the proposed June 30th.

 

*THIS WEEK’S SCHEDULE:

MONDAY:

  • UK House of Lords are to vote on the Cooper Bill brought forth last week (see below for further details)
  • Cross Party talks to continue
  • Shadow cabinet to meet today for an update on cross-party talks
  • PM May to give a statement on Brexit extension
  • PM having a meeting with a delegation of ministers on the Brexit offer to Labour at 17:00 BST
  • HoC Brexit motion 19:00 BST

TUESDAY:

  • If the Letwin-Cooper bill passes, parliament decides on the length of the extension PM May will request at Wednesday’s Brexit Summit.
  • If cross-party talks result in a compromise of some sort, this could be discussed, debated and voted on by MPs. Government could also bring forth another round of indicative votes
  • UK PM May is to meet German Chancellor Merkel tomorrow at 11:00 BST
  • PM May to meet with French President Macron

WEDNESDAY:

  • PMQs at noon
  • PM will then fly to Brussels and address the EU 27 where she will set out what can be achieved with a further extension
  • The EU Council meeting is to begin at 17:00 BST
  • EU 27 will then vote on an extension

THURSDAY:

  • PM will update parliament on the EU summit
  • MPs will vote on whether to accept the extension offered by the EU, it is not clear what will happen if this gets rejected

FRIDAY:

  • Revised date for UK to leave the EU

 

*REMINDER: LETWIN/COOPER BILL - Aimed at blocking a no-deal Brexit by forcing the Government to extend the Brexit process beyond April 12th. The bill is split in 3 sections;

  • Requires the UK PM to bring a motion to the HoC the day after the bill passes seeking an extension of any chosen length.
  • MPs are then free to change the date, binding the government.
  • If the EU responds with a different delay period, the PM must propose a fresh motion to the Commons.

This bill was passed through the HoC with a majority of one. If this deal passes through the Lords today, it will go for Royal Assent. However, if there are amendments, it will be reconsidered by the House of Commons tonight

Versum’s board has consequentially determined that this offer is “superior” and have informed Entegris that it will no longer merge with it and instead with Merck; Entegris has four days to provide a revised offer if it wishes so, and Versum must pay a USD 140mln termination fee to Entegris if it terminates the deal. Nomura quants say it would not be surprising to see some fast-type traders looking for 'cooldown' risks on US stocks
content:
• Nomura quants say March NFP was not a driver of stocks on Friday, which maintained its upward momentum: "Major trend-following algos such as CTAs and Risk Parity maintained their buying stance, while the majority of discretionary investors – such as global macro HFs and equity L/S funds – remained prudent." But the bank notes that CTAs prefered short-covering on Russell 2000 futures, the pace of adding long S&P500 and NASDAQ100 futures positions seems to have slowed, according to Nomura’s real-time estimates, and the bank reminds us that tracking whether the slowing of stock buying by CTAs is a temporary phenomenon is important for gauging market direction.
  • Nomura notes though that the US stock market sentiment index is already approaching the upper bound of +2 standard deviations from its one-year rolling average. "Given the current US stock market suggests a euphoric mood, it would not be surprising to see some fast-type participants may be watching 'cooldown' risks to some extent on US stocks," and adds that "frictions between bullish and prudent market participants should be assumed towards ~2,900 of S&P500," in the bank's view.

content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • A quiet start to the week for European trade [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%] following on from mixed trade overnight and ahead of several key events this week.
  • Reports indicate that UK PM May is to offer Labour leader Corbyn a legally binding soft Brexit, with a ‘Boris Lock’; separately, Tory MP’s may oust May if the UK partakes in EU elections or get an extension beyond June
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Factory Orders, Durables Revisions, ECB’s de Galhau, Norges Bank’s Olsen, Riksbank’s Floden

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region somewhat failed to sustain the initial momentum from last Friday’s gains on Wall St, where all majors edged higher and the S&P 500 notched a 7-day win streak after the latest NFP data. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) both opened higher with commodity-related sectors among the biggest gainers in Australia due to strength in metal prices and after WTI crude rallied to fresh YTD highs above the USD 63.00/bbl level, while risk appetite in Japan was less decisive and eventually waned as exporters contended with flows into JPY. Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) were initially buoyed on return from their extended weekend as they played catch up to the optimism from last week’s US-China trade talks in which both sides noted significant progress was made and with discussions to continue via teleconference this week, while China also plans to ease the burden on businesses in which it will reduce companies’ social insurance contributions by CNY 300bln. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated as some were kept cautious by reports that plans for a US-China joint statement hit a stalemate due to differences regarding access to China’s market. Finally, 10yr JGBs were mildly higher with prices supported as the initial positive momentum in the region waned and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 280bln in JGBs, while prices also tracked the rebound seen in T-notes in the wake of the US jobs data where weak wage growth subsequently saw the probability of a Fed rate cut this year increase to 75% before paring back to 50%.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7201 (Prev. 6.7055)

Chinese FX Reserves (USD)(Mar) 3.099tln vs. Exp. 3.095tln (Prev. 3.09tln). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Fighting between rebel forces and Libya’s UN-backed government near Tripoli resulted to 21 deaths and many injuries. (BBC)

Turkey's Erdogan says he plans to discuss in Moscow the possibility of a Turkish military operation in Syria; according to Ria. (Newswires)

UK/EU   

UK PM May could offer the Labour Party a post-Brexit customs union today, prior to this The Times reports that PM May is set to offer Jeremy Corbyn a legally binding soft Brexit deal with a “Boris lock” that would make it difficult for a future Eurosceptic prime minister to tear up after she leaves No 10. (Newswires/Times) Separately, UK Labour party want a firm indication that the government is prepared to reopen the political declaration, there may be some movement later (either talks or a new offer), according to BBC's Nick Eardley. (Twitter)

Conservative MPs are warning that they will move to remove UK PM May within weeks if the UK is forced to partake in EU elections and extend membership beyond the end of June. (Guardian)

UK government are not going to intensify preparations for a no-deal Brexit today, according to ITV's Preston citing government sources. (Twitter)

UK Cabinet meeting is likely to be cancelled tomorrow amid reports PM May will meet German Chancellor Merkel at 11:00BST, according to Telegraph's Political Editor Swinford. (Twitter) UK PM May is also scheduled to meet French President Macron on Tuesday.

Manufacturers are calling on PM May to revoke article 50 if she fails to strike a Brexit agreement next week, in the latest sign that the looming possibility of Britain leaving the EU without a deal is hammering confidence in the sector. (Times)

EQUITIES

A subdued start to the week for European equities [Stoxx 600 -0.2%] following on from a mixed Asia-Pac session as Friday’s NFP optimism waned ahead of another week filled with risk events. Broad-based losses are being experienced across major indices, whilst sectors are relatively mixed with energy names outperforming after WTI and Brent crude rallied to fresh YTD highs. In terms of individual movers, BMW (-0.4%) shares have nursed some losses after opening lower in excess of 2% amid reports that its Q1 results will be impacted by the EU fines into antitrust proceedings. This initially pressured its fellow German peers in sympathy [Daimler (-0.2%), Volkswagen (+0.4%)] who later climbed back above break-even. Sticking with Germany, Dialog Semiconductor (+1.1%) shares were bolstered amid news that the company closed a deal with US tech giant Apple (-0.4% pre-market), ahead of schedule. Finally, Fiat Chrysler (+1.3%) rose to the top of the FTSE MIB following reports the Co. signed a deal with Tesla to bypass EU emission rules. Elsewhere, Boeing (BA) CEO says they plan to cut their 737 Max monthly production by just under 20%. As such Co. are lower by 2.6% in the pre-market.

FX

USD - The Dollar continues to drift down from initial post-NFP highs as global stocks wobble and oil climbs to fresh ytd peaks. The DXY remains relatively rangebound, however, and ‘comfortably’ above the 97.000 handle within 97.230-384 parameters.

JPY/GBP - The Yen has regained a safe-haven bid and rebounded from circa 111.80 lows through 111.50 and close to the 200 DMA (111.495) vs the Greenback, while technical buying was also noted during the Asia-Pacific session in several Jpy crosses including Eur/Jpy and Nzd/Jpy that tested psychological/round number levels at 125.00 and 75.00 respectively. Meanwhile, Sterling retains an underlying bid vs the Buck above 1.3000 and is straddling 1.3050, as Eur/Gbp pivots 0.8600 in the run up to Wednesday’s EU Brexit Summit when UK PM May will present the case for another A 50 extension backed by a withdrawal plan or at least a strategy to avert no deal on April 12. On that note, she will resume talks with the Labour Party in an effort to find a compromise amidst reports that the opposition want a firm commitment to re-opening the PD rather than additions to the existing document.

EUR - The single currency is also holding above a big figure mark vs the Dollar and 2019 lows not far below 1.1200, but chart resistance around 1.1250 and a key Fib is still capping the upside, while hefty option expiry interest at 1.1225 (1.4 bn) is also weighing on the headline pair.

NZD/CAD/AUD/CHF - All relatively flat and narrowly mixed vs the Usd, as the Kiwi meanders between 0.6723-37 and also has expiries close by to exert some influence into the NY cut (1 bn at 0.6725). Elsewhere, another upturn in oil prices has helped the Loonie reverse some post-Canadian jobs data losses within a 1.3390-70 band, and is also supporting the NOK vs the Eur with the cross back down through 9.6500. Note, Barclays has shorted Eur/Nok and is looking for a move to 9.5908 with a 9.7100 stop. Elsewhere, the Aussie is hovering around 0.7100 and Franc is sitting tight near parity.

EM - The Lira has weakened even further vs the Dollar as municipal election results are recounted in Istanbul and Turkey mulls military action in Syria, while the CBRT has cut its FX swap rate by 150 bp and decided to restart 1 week refunding operations. Usd/Try up over 5.7000 and 5.7100+ at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have retreated further from overnight Eurex highs and a bit deeper below parity to a fresh 165.24 low, in stark contrast to Gilts that extended gains off the 128.00 level to 22 ticks and 21 ticks from last Friday’s close at one stage. A better than expected Eurozone Sentix survey may have prompted some core debt selling as some periphery spreads tightened and Germany’s BDB banking association called for the ECB to introduce a tiered deposit system if rates are not normalised by year end, which looks highly unlikely given the toll-back in policy guidance last month. Conversely, UK bonds spiked amidst reports highlighting tough talks between Conservative and Labour Parties on Brexit, but the 10 year benchmark has reversed in sympathy with Bunds to 127.97 since, like US Treasuries ahead of data including revisions to prelim durable good and factory orders.

COMMODITIES

Further supply-side woes have bolstered the energy complex to YTD highs with WTI and Brent futures revisiting levels last seen in November 2018 (USD 63/bbl and USD 70/bbl respectively). Gains are spurred as conflict in Libya escalates, with Hafta ordering his troops to march towards Tripoli. The fight has not yet effected oil supply, with Port Zawiya closely monitored by oil traders as it is the closest to the conflict. The port is scheduled to load 6mln barrels of crude in April which is subject to change if shipments are delayed. Amidst this, the oil complex last week saw speculators adding to their net long positive positions, with managed money positions in ICE Brent rising by just under 27k to result in net long speculative positions at almost 350k lots, the largest since the end of October 2018. Elsewhere, Saudi Energy Minister noted that he does not believe the Kingdom needs to cut output below its target, whilst a key architect of Russia’s OPEC+ deal said that the members could raise oil output in its June meeting. On the Aramco front, Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stated that the Aramco bond could attract demand north of USD 30bln (vs. touted USD 10bln) which will be used as part of a payment for the 70% purchase of Sabic (valued at USD 6.9bln).

In the metals complex, gold prices are underpinned as the Greenback softened overnight and continues to pull back during the European session thus far. Demand for the yellow metal was also reflected in an increase in China’s gold reserves which showed the fourth consecutive month of gold purchases. Elsewhere, copper benefitted amid overnight gains across Chinese commodity prices in which Dalian iron ore futures extended on record highs, while Shanghai rebar and hot rolled coil rallied over 3% shortly after the open.

Saudi Energy Minister Al- Falih says he does not believe the kingdom needs to cut output below its target. (Newswires)

- Also, reaffirms commitment to being a stabilizing force in energy markets

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih says the Aramco bond deal is to close on Wednesday; adds that the demand for the bond could be above USD 30bln. Subsequently, reported that Saudi Aramco may price its bond on Tuesday afternoon UK time; Saudi Aramco are to open books for their debut international bond later today., according to sources. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister Al Mazroui says OPEC and allies expect good April compliance numbers

content: Gilts have resumed Liffe in a tight range and mostly above their previous 128.01 settlement price, while the Short Sterling strip is 0.5-1 tick ahead and just shy of early highs that saw the Dec20 contract trade 1.5 ticks better at one stage. The marginally firmer tone is in keeping with trade elsewhere and in contrast to a downturn in EU equities, albeit relatively contained, but UK markets are also braced for yet another pivotal week on the Brexit front given Friday’s A 50 deadline unless PM May can get Parliament back for a plan to trigger a further extension in time for the EU Summit. So it could all come down to the next 48 hours rather than 5 full days, and in particular talks between May and her Labour counterpart.

Bunds have not really reacted to German trade even though exports and imports were both considerably weaker than forecast in February, and are unlikely to be too responsive to the upcoming Eurozone Sentix index, but could glean some impetus from ECB’s de Galhau later, although in truth the comments should not be policy related given the purdah ahead of Wednesday’s meeting.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

8th April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region somewhat failed to sustain the initial momentum from last Friday’s gains on Wall St, where all majors edged higher and the S&P 500 notched a 7-day win streak after the latest NFP data. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) both opened higher with commodity-related sectors among the biggest gainers in Australia due to strength in metal prices and after WTI crude rallied to fresh YTD highs above the USD 63.00/bbl level, while risk appetite in Japan was less decisive and eventually waned as exporters contended with flows into JPY. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were initially buoyed on return from their extended weekend as they played catch up to the optimism from last week’s US-China trade talks in which both sides noted significant progress was made and with discussions to continue via teleconference this week, while China also plans to ease the burden on businesses in which it will reduce companies’ social insurance contributions by CNY 300bln. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated as some were kept cautious by reports that plans for a US-China joint statement hit a stalemate due to differences regarding access to China’s market.

FTSE

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co. is poised to be questioned on issues from job cuts as investors are keen for an update on Co.’s decision to close fresh food counters at 90 stores, putting up to 9000 jobs at risk. In related news, Co. are set to unveil its biggest profit since CEO Dave Lewis joined the Co. five years ago, signalling a recovery from its crisis. Tesco are set to report its annual results on Wednesday. Separately, Co. is reportedly working on a new loyalty scheme, echoing Amazon Prime, which would give “tens of millions” of customers a greater incentive to sign up to Tesco’s banking and mobile phone services. (The Times/ The Telegraph) 

Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN) – MPs have asked the Prudential Regulation Authority to investigate Co. bosses, including its CEO for alleged “covering up” of the HBOS Reading fraud. (The Times)

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co’s shareholders have stated they will withdraw a resolution regarding the Co’s environmental targets, stating the Co. is now a ‘industry leader’ in emissions targets, and their focus will now move to other Co’s environmental goals. (FT)

UK Technology Names – Government are to impose a new ‘duty of care’ on Co’s, making them take measures to combat illegal and harmful activities on their services; citing plans which are due to be announced in a White Paper today. (FT)

Schroders (SDR LN) – Shareholder Nick Train has doubled his stake in the Co’s to 8%, and has stated the Co. needs to invest in the North American market. (FT)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Greencoat capital are in discussions to launch a new fund aimed at the GBP 4bln sell off of a minor stake in the UK’s nuclear reactors from the Co. and EDF (EDF FP). (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

EASYJET (EZJ LN) UPGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

DAX

BMW (BMW GY) – Co. are to set aside over EUR 1bln in relation to fines from an EU investigation into anti-trust proceedings. Co. state this will negatively impact Q1 2019 financial results. Co. add that a final evaluation of this impact is not currently possible, and Co’s FY guidance remains unchanged. (FT/Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/ Commerzbank (CBK GY) – Deutsche Bank is reportedly open to further restructure its US business during merger talks with Commerzbank. Restructuring may include further cutbacks in US equities and corporate finance, according to sources. In related news, European Bank Supervisors want to set tough standards for a possible merger between the two banks whilst demanding a detail plan of staff cuts to check whether the merger makes sense commercially. A prelim decision on the banks’ merger should happen by mid-April, according to Handelsblatt citing sources. (Newswires/Handelsblatt)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

FRAPORT (FRA GY) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

CONTINENTAL (CON GY) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT KEPLER CHEUVREUX

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Boeing (BA) CEO said that the Co. plans to cut its 737 Max monthly production by almost 20% to 42 aircrafts per month (Prev. 52) starting mid-April. (The Guardian)

Renault (RNO FP) – Nissan shareholders have voted to remove former Chairman Ghosn from the Co’s board. (FT)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES                          

Air France KLM (AF FP) – March passenger numbers +3.4% Y/Y to 8.3mln passengers, March load factor -0.3ppts Y/Y to 87.6%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ICADE (ICAD FP) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT KEPLER CHEUVREUX

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • A mixed start to the week for Asian indices, as Friday’s momentum fades and markets catch up from their extended weekend
  • On the Brexit front, the government is prepared to change the Political Declaration to achieve a deal while the EU thinks May’s short extension is risky
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Trade, US Factory Orders, Durables Revisions, ECB’s de Galhau, BoC’s Wilkins, Norges Bank’s Olsen, Riksbank’s Floden

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week mixed as the region somewhat failed to sustain the initial momentum from last Friday’s gains on Wall St, where all majors edged higher and the S&P 500 notched a 7-day win streak after the latest NFP data. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) both opened higher with commodity-related sectors among the biggest gainers in Australia due to strength in metal prices and after WTI crude rallied to fresh YTD highs above the USD 63.00/bbl level, while risk appetite in Japan was less decisive and eventually waned as exporters contended with flows into JPY. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were initially buoyed on return from their extended weekend as they played catch up to the optimism from last week’s US-China trade talks in which both sides noted significant progress was made and with discussions to continue via teleconference this week, while China also plans to ease the burden on businesses in which it will reduce companies’ social insurance contributions by CNY 300bln. However, the mainland gradually deteriorated as some were kept cautious by reports that plans for a US-China joint statement hit a stalemate due to differences regarding access to China’s market. Finally, 10yr JGBs were mildly higher with prices supported as the initial positive momentum in the region waned and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 280bln in JGBs, while prices also tracked the rebound seen in T-notes in the wake of the US jobs data where weak wage growth subsequently saw the probability of a Fed rate cut this year increase to 75% before paring back to 50%.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7201 (Prev. 6.7055)

China and EU leaders' plans for a joint statement hit an impasse amid opposing views on the extent of how much access to China's market should be improved. (SCMP)

Chinese FX Reserves (USD)(Mar) 3.099tln vs. Exp. 3.095tln (Prev. 3.09tln). (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK government spokesperson said the government is prepared to seek changes to the political declaration in order to deliver a deal that is acceptable to both sides. (FT) The Times reports that PM May is set to offer Jeremy Corbyn a legally binding soft Brexit deal with a “Boris lock” that would make it difficult for a future Eurosceptic prime minister to tear up after she leaves No 10. Times) Conservative MPs are warning that they will move to remove UK PM May within weeks if the UK is forced to partake in EU elections and extend membership beyond the end of June. (Guardian)

UK opposition Labour party said "we are disappointed that the government has not offered real change or compromise and urge the PM to come forward with genuine changes according to Business Insider's Payne, while ITV Political Editor Peston noted the UK government and opposition Labour party talks to end Brexit deadlock are close to collapsing. (Business Insider/ITV)

EU reportedly thinks UK PM May's request for a short delay to Brexit is "very risky" if MPs don’t approve the prime minister’s Brexit deal before the extension is granted. (BuzzFeed)

Manufacturers are calling on PM May to revoke article 50 if she fails to strike a Brexit agreement next week, in the latest sign that the looming possibility of Britain leaving the EU without a deal is hammering confidence in the sector. (Times)

Fitch affirmed Belgium at 'AA-'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, price action was relatively quiet and typical of the post-NFP lull in which the DXY gave back some of its recent gain. This helped its major European counterparts recover recent lost ground with EUR/USD now lingering near a large option expiry of EUR 1.4bln at 1.1225, while GBP/USD resumed its rebound from support around 1.3000. Conversely, antipodeans remained hampered by the current dovish consensus for their respective central banks and with AUD/USD dejected after it slipped below the 0.7100 handle, while USD/JPY was lower amid a deterioration of risk appetite and technical selling in related crosses in which EUR/JPY and NZD/JPY tested support at the 125.00 and the 75.00 levels respectively.

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were higher overnight in which WTI crude futures extended on the post-NFP gains to print a fresh YTD high above the USD 63.00/bbl level after Friday’s US jobs data and supply side factors including further sanctions on Venezuela’s PDVSA and with the escalating situation in Libya where 21 were killed in a battle between the UN-backed government and rebel forces attempting to capture Tripoli. Elsewhere, gold prices were mildly underpinned as the greenback softened overnight and copper benefitted amid gains across Chinese commodity prices in which Dalian iron ore futures extended on record highs, while Shanghai rebar and hot rolled coil rallied over 3% shortly after the open.

 

Baker Hughes (April 5): oil rigs +15 at 851, gas rigs +4 at 194, total rigs +19 at 1025. (Newswires)

 

White House is planning an executive order which aims to boost pipeline construction and lower energy prices. (CNBC)

US was reportedly mulling further sanctions on Venezuela financial sector and is also sanctioning 34 ships owned/operated by PDVSA. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Fighting between rebel forces and Libya’s UN-backed government near Tripoli resulted to 21 deaths and many injuries. (BBC)

US

Treasuries initially had a downward bias on Friday after US President Trump talked about reaching a trade deal with China within four weeks, while his Chinese counterpart were also optimistic. Selling resumed after German industrial production beat expectations, after a run where manufacturing data had been grim (however, the sector remains in recession). There was two-way action during the payrolls report, with upside being seen on a weaker wages number, though sellers were latching on to the above-trend headline. The probability of a Fed rate cut this year rose to 75% after the data, though pared back to around 50% as the dust settled. The Treasury complex remained near highs after Trump reiterated his preference for loose monetary policy. At settlement, curve spreads were slightly narrower. US T-note futures (M9) settled 1+ ticks higher at 123-19.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher as the region reacts to US jobs data and China plays catch up to the trade optimism
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week mostly positive following last Friday’s gains on Wall St, where all majors edged higher and the S&P 500 notched a 7-day win streak after better than expected NFP jobs data. Nonetheless, ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) are mixed with commodity-related sectors among the biggest gainers in Australia due to strength in metal prices and after WTI crude rallied to fresh YTD highs above the USD 63.00/bbl level, while Japanese trade was less decisive as risk sentiment contended with flows into JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) are buoyed on return from their extended weekend as they play catch up to the optimism from last week’s US-China trade talks in which both sides noted significant progress was made and with discussions to continue via teleconference this week, while China also plans further efforts to support business in which it will reduce companies’ social insurance contributions by CNY 300bln.

In FX markets, price action is relatively quiet which is typical of the post-NFP lull with the DXY just giving back some of the gains seen after the better than expected job numbers. This has helped its major European counterparts recover some of the recent lost ground with EUR/USD now lingering near a large option expiry of EUR 1.4bln at 1.1225, while GBP/USD resumes its rebound from support around 1.3000 where some analysts noted a bullish dragonfly doji pattern had formed on the 30 minute chart. Conversely, AUD and NZD are lacklustre despite the mostly positive risk tone and gains across commodities, as the antipodeans remain hampered by the current dovish consensus for their respective central banks and with AUD/USD dejected after a slip below the 0.7100 handle. USD/JPY is lower amid a deterioration of risk appetite in Japan and amid technical selling in related crosses in which EUR/JPY and NZD/JPY tested support at the 125.00 and the 75.00 levels respectively.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are mildly higher with prices supported as the initial positive momentum in Japanese stocks gradually waned and with the BoJ present in the market for JPY 280bln in JGBs, while prices also track the rebound seen in T-notes in the wake of the US jobs data where weak wage growth subsequently saw the probability of a Fed rate cut this year increase to 75% before paring back to 50%.
